subject_terms_3: Oil painting Force 136 (Guerilla movement) Tan, Chong Tee 1942-1945 Japanese occupation Lim, Bo Seng
physical_appearance: This oil painting is a commemoration of the 50th Anniversary of the Death of Lim Bo Seng. It features a montage of media coverage and attendees at the memorial event. The foreground shows a collage of media materials including newspapers and books. The background of the painting features a pagoda in the center, against the cityscape. The center of the painting is filled with a depiction of the crowd at the event, blending into portraits of significant figures who attended the memorial. There is a signature at the top-right of the painting.
sgcool_label_text:
This painting belongs to a larger part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the mid-1990s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

This painting commemorates the 50th anniversary of the death of martyr Lim Bo Seng and features a montage of the media coverage and attendees of the event.
